Class Comb

All Implemented Interfaces:

Direct Known Subclasses:
IntroComb
public class Comb extends Cocktail
Comb Sort is a comparison-based sorting algorithm that is an improvement over Bubble Sort. It works by repeatedly comparing and swapping elements with a specific gap value, gradually reducing the gap until it reaches 1, at which point the algorithm performs a final pass similar to Bubble Sort.
Since:
1.0

  • Constructor Details

    • Comb

      public Comb()
      Comb Sort:
      Is a comparison-based sorting algorithm that is an improvement over Bubble Sort. It works by repeatedly comparing and swapping elements with a specific gap value, gradually reducing the gap until it reaches 1, at which point the algorithm performs a final pass similar to Bubble Sort.

      Example:
      1. Start with an unsorted list of elements.
      2. Initialize the gap value as the length of the list.
      3. Repeat the following steps until the gap becomes 1:
        • Calculate the new gap value by dividing the current gap by a shrink factor, typically around
          1.3 (commonly denoted as 1.3 or 1.3-sqrt(2)).
        • If the new gap value is less than 1, set it to 1 to ensure a final pass with a gap of 1.
        • Perform a pass through the list, comparing elements that are gap positions apart and swapping them if they are in the wrong order.
        • Continue moving through the list with the specified gap until reaching the end of the list.
      4. Once the gap becomes 1, perform a final pass similar to Bubble Sort, comparing adjacent elements and swapping them if necessary.
      5. The sorted list is obtained once the final pass is completed.
      Note:
      The key idea behind Comb Sort is to eliminate the "turtle" effect in Bubble Sort, where small elements at the end of the list take a long time to move towards their correct positions. By gradually reducing the gap, Comb Sort helps bring such elements closer to their correct positions earlier in the sorting process.

      Comb Sort has a time complexity of O(n^2) in the worst case, but it can be improved to have an average time complexity of O(n log(n)) by using an optimal shrink factor.

      Comb Sort is an in-place sorting algorithm, meaning it requires only a constant amount of additional memory beyond the original list. It is relatively easy to implement and can be useful in certain scenarios where simplicity and memory efficiency are priorities.

      Property:
      Worst Case Complexity: O(n^2)
      Best Case Complexity: O(n log(n))
      Average Case Complexity: O(n^2 / 2^p) where p is the number of increments
      Auxiliary Space: O(1)
      Stability: Yes
      See Also:
      • IntroComb
      • IntroDPQComb

    • combInc

      protected void combInc(Comparable[] array)
      combInc that implements the comb sort algorithm to sort an array of Comparable objects in increasing order.
      • The method takes an array of Comparable objects, denoted by array, and performs the comb sort algorithm on it.
      • The variable n is assigned the length of the array, representing the total number of elements in the array.
      • The variable gap is initially set to n, representing the initial gap value for comparisons and swaps.
      • The swapped variable is initially set to true, indicating that there may be swaps to perform in the array.
      • The outer while loop continues as long as the gap is not equal to 1 or there are still swaps being made in the array.
      • Inside the while loop, the getNextGap method is called to calculate the next gap value based on the current gap.
      • The for loop iterates from 0 to (n - gap), performing comparisons and swaps between elements with a specific gap.
      • Inside the for loop, the isSwap method is called to determine if a swap is necessary between two elements with the given gap. If a swap is made, the swapped variable is set to true.
      • After the for loop, the outer while loop continues until the gap becomes 1 and no more swaps are made in the array.
      combInc the Comb Sort algorithm is an improvement over the Bubble Sort algorithm. It starts with a large gap value and gradually reduces it in each iteration. The goal is to eliminate small values at the end of the array quickly. The algorithm continues until the gap becomes 1, which is equivalent to a regular Bubble Sort pass with adjacent element comparisons and swaps.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      See Also:
      • getNextGap(int)
      • SortSwap.isSwapInc(Comparable[], int, int)

    • combInc

      protected void combInc(Comparable[] array, int left, int right)
      combInc that implements the comb sort algorithm to sort an array of Comparable objects in increasing order.
      • The method takes an array of Comparable objects, denoted by array, and performs the comb sort algorithm on it.
      • The variable right is assigned the length of the array, representing the total number of elements in the array.
      • The variable gap is initially set to right, representing the initial gap value for comparisons and swaps.
      • The swapped variable is initially set to true, indicating that there may be swaps to perform in the array.
      • The outer while loop continues as long as the gap is not equal to 1 or there are still swaps being made in the array.
      • Inside the while loop, the getNextGap method is called to calculate the next gap value based on the current gap.
      • The for loop iterates from 0 to (right - gap), performing comparisons and swaps between elements with a specific gap.
      • Inside the for loop, the isSwap method is called to determine if a swap is necessary between two elements with the given gap. If a swap is made, the swapped variable is set to true.
      • After the for loop, the outer while loop continues until the gap becomes 1 and no more swaps are made in the array.
      combInc the Comb Sort algorithm is an improvement over the Bubble Sort algorithm. It starts with a large gap value and gradually reduces it in each iteration. The goal is to eliminate small values at the end of the array quickly. The algorithm continues until the gap becomes 1, which is equivalent to a regular Bubble Sort pass with adjacent element comparisons and swaps.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      left - the value in the array must be smaller than a right parameter.
      right - the value in the array must be greater than a left parameter.
      See Also:
      • getNextGap(int)
      • SortSwap.isSwapInc(Comparable[], int, int)

    • combDec

      protected void combDec(Comparable[] array, int left, int right)
      combDec that implements the comb sort algorithm to sort an array of Comparable objects in decreasing order.
      • The method takes an array of Comparable objects, denoted by array, and performs the comb sort algorithm on it.
      • The variable right is assigned the length of the array, representing the total number of elements in the array.
      • The variable gap is initially set to right, representing the initial gap value for comparisons and swaps.
      • The swapped variable is initially set to true, indicating that there may be swaps to perform in the array.
      • The outer while loop continues as long as the gap is not equal to 1 or there are still swaps being made in the array.
      • Inside the while loop, the getNextGap method is called to calculate the next gap value based on the current gap.
      • The for loop iterates from 0 to (right - gap), performing comparisons and swaps between elements with a specific gap.
      • Inside the for loop, the isSwap method is called to determine if a swap is necessary between two elements with the given gap. If a swap is made, the swapped variable is set to true.
      • After the for loop, the outer while loop continues until the gap becomes 1 and no more swaps are made in the array.
      combDec the Comb Sort algorithm is an improvement over the Bubble Sort algorithm. It starts with a large gap value and gradually reduces it in each iteration. The goal is to eliminate small values at the end of the array quickly. The algorithm continues until the gap becomes 1, which is equivalent to a regular Bubble Sort pass with adjacent element comparisons and swaps.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      left - the value in the array must be smaller than a right parameter.
      right - the value in the array must be greater than a left parameter.
      See Also:

    • getNextGap

      protected int getNextGap(int gap)
      getNextGap that calculates the next gap value to be used in the Comb Sort algorithm. The gap value determines the interval between elements being compared and swapped during each iteration of the sort.
      • The method takes an integer gap as input and calculates the next gap value to be used.
      • The expression gap = ((gap * 10) / 13) calculates the next gap by multiplying the current gap by 10 and then dividing it by 13. The multiplication and division operations are used to adjust the gap value.
      • The condition if (gap < 1) checks if the calculated gap value is less than 1. If so, it sets the gap value to 1. This ensures that the gap value never becomes zero or negative.
      • Finally, the method returns the calculated or adjusted gap value.
      getNextGap method is commonly used in comb sort algorithms to determine the next gap value during each iteration. The gap is gradually reduced until it becomes 1, at which point the algorithm performs a final pass with a gap of 1 to ensure full sorting. The specific formula used to calculate the next gap value may vary depending on the implementation.
      Parameters:
      gap - value to be used.
      Returns:
      the calculated or adjusted gap value.
